data.title: New Quiz: Which iconic gadget is now defunct after the company announced it will no longer support its software?
Cyber Ninjas, company that oversaw the partisan Arizona election review, is shuttering
data.description: The Cyber Ninjas firm that oversaw the problem-plagued review of the 2020 results in Arizona's Maricopa County is shuttering.

data.title: Many employees could be in for pay hikes of 5% or more in 2022
data.description: As the "Great Resignation" spurs a war for talent, some companies expect to step up with bigger raises this year.

data.title: Liberty Global stands by board member John Dick despite daughter's theft claims
data.description: Liberty Global, the largest international TV and broadband company, is standing by embattled board member John W. Dick, saying he serves in good standing.

data.title: Big Tech could brush off rate hikes. Startups may struggle
data.description: Apple, Microsoft, SoFi and Coinbase all sold off sharply this week, as investors, anticipating higher interest rates, dumped tech stocks and bought shares of companies they believed were undervalued.

data.title: SpaceX's Starlink internet service has more than 145,000 users so far
data.description: Elon Musk's SpaceX on Thursday gave an update on its Starlink internet service, as the company launched more satellites into orbit.

data.title: Stocks making the biggest moves after hours: GameStop, Quidel & T-Mobile
data.description: Check out the companies making headlines in after-hours trading.

data.title: December jobs report expected to be strong, with no impact yet from omicron
data.description: Hiring was expected to have been strong in December, even as some companies asked employees to temporarily work from home due to the spread of Covid.

data.title: New York Times announces plans to buy The Athletic for $550 million
data.description: The New York Times struck a deal to acquire sports news site The Athletic, the company announced Thursday.

data.title: On the anniversary of January 6, social media platforms are on high alert
data.description: January 6 was a clear turning point for major social media companies — proving that they would, under certain circumstances, be willing to deplatform a sitting US president. But some experts worry that they still haven't done enough to address the underlying issues that allowed Trump supporters and others on the far-right to be misled and radicalized, and to get organized using their platforms.
